Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative: ABI Development: Synthetic Biology Open Language Resource
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Washington and the University of Utah are awarded collaborative grants to develop and encourage the use of standards in the new engineering field of synthetic biology where biological systems are engineered to help manufacture drugs, biofuels, novel materials or more advanced applications such as new approaches to processing information. All engineering benefits from the use of standards. Examples include the standardization of screw and bolt sizes, standard voltages in computer electronic circuits, or internet standards that drive the World Wide Web. In each of these cases the use of standards has made many new industries economically viable which in turn has yielded enormous dividends to society. A nascent and growing community of synthetic biology researchers across industry and academia has come to recognize the value of standards, and worked together to develop the Synthetic Biology Open Language (SBOL), a standard that can describe biological designs constructed from DNA. This project will build from this starting place to (a) strengthen and extend SBOL so that it can serve a wider range of uses, (b) develop validation suites and services, so that systems can verify correct use of the standard, and (c) perform outreach and education to further grow and build our community of users and developers in both academia and industry. The key driving force for the development these standards will be the synthetic biology community. Our essential role is to put in place the means by which the whole community can benefit from a single standard that all can all agree to.

The project also has in place a number of outreach efforts that will benefit society directly. At the educational level, a special relationship with a community driven effort called HiveBio (http://hivebio.org/) will help high school students and laypeople understand modern biotechnology and molecular biology through hands-on classes. Every year the project will help fund up to 30 individuals to learn about genetic engineering, the techniques that scientists use in the lab and the ethical issues that we potentially face in biotechnology. Two of the researchers on the project also publish undergraduate textbooks on synthetic biology and cellular modeling and will publish second editions of the books during the lifetime of the project. The project will hold biannual meetings where researchers from academia and industry will be able to discuss future developments for the standard and to further build the community. In addition to developing an active community website, the communities' work will be presented at workshops and cross-disciplinary groups engaged in work such as systems biology, and e-science. Project staff will also present at the Seattle science clubs where the general public can learn more about synthetic biology in general. The Synthetic Biology Open Language can be accessed at http://www.sbolstandard.org.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Synthetic biology is the engineering discipline dedicated to creating novel biological systems for the purpose of understanding fundamental biological phenomena or applications such as biofuels, bioremediation, and medicine. The goal of this project was the continued development of the Synthetic Biology Open Language (SBOL) standard. SBOL developed out of a grass-root effort to formalize the description of synthetic biology designs. Since then, the effort has grown with regular workshops, a website that includes specification and use case information, and a developers group with more than 150 members from more than 70 academic and industrial organizations. The effort is also international with active participation from the UK and other countries. SBOL was mentioned in the UK roadmap (July 2012) for synthetic biology as “an essential step in the translation/industrialization process for synthetic biology” and has been adopted by many software tools.

This project had two major goals to further SBOL's development and sustainability.  First, this project would continue to develop the necessary bioinformatic and computational infrastructure required to help the community develop further.  To this end, PI Myers, PI Sauro, our students, and our collaborators developed four software libraries for SBOL for the most common programming languages: Java, Javascript, C++, and Python.  These libraries enable developers of software tools for synthetic biology to easily add support for SBOL within their tools.  In addition, PI Myers and his collaborators at Newcastle University developed several software tools to support the synthetic biology design workflow using these libraries.  These included sequence editing tools (SBOLDesigner), genetic circuit visualization tools (VisBol), modeling and analysis tools (iBioSim), and data repositories (SynBioHub).  

The second goal of this project was to continue to develop the community organization to encourage and coordinate the widespread use and development of SBOL both in the US and internationally.  To this end, in coordination with the COmputational Modeling in BIology NEtwork (COMBINE), we helped organize 11 workshops to gather interested parties to work on the SBOL data standard.  In coordination with the International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA), we also helped organize and lead 4 developer workshops to help educate software developers on how to integrate SBOL into their tools.  In coordination with the Synthetic Biology: Engineering, Evolution & Design (SEED) Conference, we helped organize 2 software user workshops to help educate the users of SBOL compliant software.  Finally, the PIs and their students have given numerous talks about SBOL and related software efforts at a variety of academic, government, and industrial venues.
